title: RSI Momentum Indicator
text: RSI measures momentum on a 0-100 scale, calculated from average gains and losses over a lookback period. It is one of the most widely used oscillators in technical analysis.

title: VWAP Execution Benchmark
text: VWAP is the volume-weighted average price, used as a benchmark for execution quality. It represents the average price a security has traded at throughout the day, weighted by volume.

title: Stop-Loss Order Concept
text: A stop-loss is a preset exit order that limits downside risk on a position. When the price reaches the stop level, the order becomes a market order and the position is closed.

title: Pairs Trading Overview
text: Pairs trading is a market-neutral strategy that involves simultaneously buying and selling two correlated securities. Profits are made when the price spread between the pair reverts to its historical mean.

title: Bollinger Bands Description
text: Bollinger Bands consist of a middle band (typically a 20-period SMA) and upper and lower bands set at a specified number of standard deviations. They are used to identify overbought and oversold conditions.

title: Value at Risk Definition
text: Value at Risk (VaR) estimates the maximum expected loss over a given time horizon at a specified confidence level. It is a standard risk measure used across financial institutions.

title: Sector Rotation Concept
text: Sector rotation is an investment strategy that involves moving capital between different industry sectors based on the business cycle. Investors shift from cyclical to defensive sectors during economic downturns.

title: Market Impact Definition
text: Market impact refers to the price change caused by a trade itself. Large orders tend to move prices against the trader, and impact models estimate this cost as a function of order size and market liquidity.

title: Factor Investing Basics
text: Factor investing targets specific drivers of return such as value, momentum, size, quality, and low volatility. Academic research has shown these factors earn premiums over long horizons.

title: Implied Volatility Overview
text: Implied volatility is derived from option prices and represents the market's expectation of future price movement. Higher implied volatility indicates greater expected price fluctuation.

title: RSI Oversold Trading Practice
text: Many traders consider RSI below 30 as an oversold signal suggesting potential mean reversion. This is a widely known practice described in most technical analysis textbooks and courses.

title: Pairs Trading Spread Practice
text: Pairs trading involves finding two correlated securities and trading their spread when it diverges. Practitioners typically use z-scores of the spread to identify entry and exit points.

title: VWAP Execution Practice
text: VWAP strategies are commonly used by institutional investors to minimize market impact. Orders are sliced across the day proportional to historical volume profiles.

title: Risk Parity Allocation Practice
text: Risk parity allocates capital inversely proportional to asset volatility so each asset contributes equally to portfolio risk. This approach has been popularized by several large hedge funds.

title: Momentum Factor Practice
text: Cross-sectional momentum strategies rank stocks by past returns and go long winners while shorting losers. A common implementation uses 12-month returns excluding the most recent month.

title: Variance Risk Premium Practice
text: Selling options to capture the variance risk premium is a well-documented strategy. Implied volatility tends to exceed realized volatility on average, creating a systematic premium for option sellers.

title: Post-Earnings Drift Practice
text: Post-earnings announcement drift is a well-known anomaly where stocks with positive earnings surprises tend to continue outperforming for weeks after the announcement.

title: Factor Neutralization Practice
text: Institutional portfolios often neutralize exposure to common risk factors like market beta, size, and value to isolate alpha. This is standard practice in quantitative equity management.

title: Dark Pool Routing Practice
text: Institutional investors commonly route a portion of their order flow through dark pools to reduce market impact and information leakage on large block trades.

title: Drawdown Management Practice
text: Most institutional funds implement drawdown-based risk controls that reduce position sizes or halt trading when portfolio losses exceed predefined thresholds during a given period.
